content.question: A <math alttext="5.00 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-sample of <math alttext="K O H solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25.0 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.0</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was added to <math alttext="100.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at room temperature inside an insulated cup calorimeter, and the contents were stirred. After all the <math alttext="K O H solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolved, the temperature of the solution had increased. Based on the information given, which of the following best justifies the claim that the dissolution of <math alttext="K O H solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is a thermodynamically favorable process?

choices.label: The forces between the ions and the water molecules are stronger than the forces between water molecules, thus <math alttext="delta H is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Also, the ions become less dispersed as <math alttext="K O H solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves, thus <math alttext="delta S is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, <math alttext="delta G is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The energy required to break the bonds between the ions in the solid is less than that released as the ion-dipole attractions form during solvation, thus <math alttext="delta H is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Also, the ions become more widely dispersed as <math alttext="K O H solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves, thus <math alttext="delta S is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, <math alttext="delta G is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The average kinetic energy of the particles increases, resulting in <math alttext="delta H is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Also, the ions become more widely dispersed as <math alttext="K O H solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves, thus <math alttext="delta S is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, <math alttext="delta G is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The average kinetic energy of the particles increases, resulting in <math alttext="delta H is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Also, the ions become more widely dispersed as <math alttext="K O H solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves, thus <math alttext="delta S is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, <math alttext="delta G is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The energy required to break the bonds between the ions in the solid is less than that released as the ion-dipole attractions form during solvation, thus <math alttext="delta H is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Also, the ions become more widely dispersed as <math alttext="K O H solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves, thus <math alttext="delta S is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Therefore, <math alttext="delta G is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 9.3: Gibbs Free Energy and Thermodynamic Favorability

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
